stem: The nurse is performing a total body skin assessment on a client with a history of extensive sun exposure. Based on the documentation in the Dermatology Assessment Map, match each characteristic with its significance.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: Patient: Sarah, 55 years old. Fair-skinned with a history of 10+ blistering sunburns in childhood. Reports a 'new mole' on her back that has recently started to itch.

tabs.title: Dermatology Assessment Map
tabs.content:
Lesion IDColorMarginsSymmetryDiameter / Elevation
Lesion 1Uniform BrownSharp; SmoothSymmetrical4 mm; Flat
Lesion 2Variegated (Blue/Black)Blurred; RaggedAsymmetrical7 mm; Raised
Lesion 3Uniform TanSmoothSymmetrical2 mm; Flat (Freckle)

tabs.title: Physical Findings
tabs.content: Lesion 2: Located on the upper right scapula. Client reports it has 'grown significantly' over the last 3 months.

rows.text: Asymmetry (one half does not match the other)
Border irregularity (edges are ragged, notched, or blurred)
Color variation (tones of brown, black, blue, or red within one lesion)
Diameter > 6 mm (about the size of a pencil eraser)
Evolving (changes in size, shape, or symptomatic itching/bleeding)

rationale.correct: Each row listed (r1-r5) is a classic 'red flag' for malignant melanoma (ABCDE rule). Asymmetry (A), Border (B), Color (C), Diameter (D), and Evolving (E) are the criteria used to differentiate cancerous lesions from benign moles (c2).
clinicalPearls: Melanoma is the deadliest form of skin cancer because it metastasizes early.
The 'ugly duckling' sign: A mole that looks significantly different from all other moles on the body.
Patients should perform skin self-exams monthly.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a mole is 'fine' because it doesn't hurt.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Cancerous moles are often painless. It is the change (evolution) and the shape that matter most.
